You used a similar method that is used to convert corn into HFCS. The glucose is difficult to work with for some types of candy such as cotton candy due to the crystalline structure. It was brown because sugars tend to be brown unless they are processed into white table sugar. Pure cane sugar is brown. The cotton candy melted so quickly due to the humidity in the lab. Sugars crystalline structure changes with different levels of melting and resolidification. You may have had a bit more success if instead of caramalizing it, make a 50/50 syrup and double boiled it until you reached what is called the "hardball stage". This means when you submerge a drop of molten sugar into ice water it instantly balls up into a hard piece of candy. Then, if you had ground it into a fine powder I feel the cotton candy would have turned out closer to what is industrially made.

In the future if you are going to perform an ion exchange using that type of resin, i suggest to buy both cationic and anionic ones.
If you need to remove any ions from your solution you need to pass your solution in both the resin bed.
Also you need to buy the R-H and R-OH ones and not the R-Na one, so you will be left with a nice and pure deminerized solution.
Also if you want to optimize the resin consumption after a couple passes on the cationic one, heat the solution, so if there were any traces of carbonic acid, it will be released in air in CO2 form and you will save a bunch of anionic resin for the exchange of CO3-- ions

The reason this didn't work as intended is the reaction produced glucose, however cotton candy is made of molten sucrose, the reacting of the glucose does help however it doesnt turn the glucose into sucrose, for that you would need to react the glucose with fructose in the presence of Sucrose Synthase, to be more specific the glucose would need to be either in the form of Uridine Diphosphate Glucose(UDP-G) or Adenosine Diphosphate Glucose(ADP-G)

Btw. try to crush the suger and air dry it a bit more after the proses. you can't get it white or completely transparent because you need to extract the molasses from the sugar. Then it will become white and after that the crystalesetion comes from vacuum that comepletely dry out the water in the sugar. The vacuum is also better then overly airdry it, because it does not add heat into the sugar, which can in worst case make it burn. Sugar melt at 160 degrees (or to be exact: 162 degrees Celsius = 323.6 degrees Fahrenheit) if you turn it up just a bit more, it will burn, because sugar is very sensitive to heat as well as cold air or liquid. when you are done, crush the sugar before porring it into the candyfloss mashine. And the main reason for the wierd outcome is deffently the lack of extract of molasses. Molasses is a bit gooey colorfull and watery. I think it most deffently react posetively to high pressure vacuum. Good luck for the next time. :) 👍

Nile red (also known as Nile blue oxazone) is a lipophilic stain. Nile red stains intracellular lipid droplets yellow. In most polar solvents, Nile red will not fluoresce; however, when in a lipid-rich environment, it can be intensely fluorescent, with varying colours from deep red (for polar membrane lipid) to strong yellow-gold emission (for neutral lipid in intracellular storages). The dye is highly solvatochromic and its emission and excitation wavelength both shift depending on solvent polarity[1] and in polar media will hardly fluoresce at all.[2]

Nile red has applications in cell biology, where it can be used as a membrane dye which can be readily visualized using an epifluorescence microscope with excitation and emission wavelengths usually shared with red fluorescent protein. Nile red has also been used as part of a sensitive detection process for microplastics in bottled water.[3][4] Additionally, nile red is a remarkable candidator in fabricating membrane for different sensors to detect environmental changes, such as taste, gas, pH, etc.[5]

In triglycerides (a neutral lipid), Nile red has an excitation maximum of about 515 nm (green), and emission maximum of about 585 nm (yellow-orange).[6] In contrast, in phospholipids (polar lipids), Nile red has an excitation maximum of about 554 nm (green), and an emission maximum of about 638 nm (red).[7]

Synthesis
Nile red can be prepared through acid hydrolysis by boiling a solution of Nile blue with sulfuric acid.[8] This process replaces an iminium group with a carbonyl group. Alternatively, Nile red and its analogs (naphthooxazine dyes) can be prepared by acid-catalyzed condensation of corresponding 5-(dialkylamino)-2-nitrosophenols with 2-naphthol. The yields are generally moderate as no co-oxidant is used in this procedure.[9] Since the reaction to generate Nile red does not usually completely exhaust the supply of Nile blue, additional separation steps are required if pure Nile red is needed.

It’s interesting to see how everything in the chemical world is stitched together with our everyday items. As a graduate student studying organic chemistry, I often feel at times that making a molecule can be a bit mundane. Not even gonna lie. It gets downright depressing when things don’t work, and your boss chews you out. Anyway, watching these videos keeps me motivated because it goes to show that theres always a solution when you need it. Hell, you literally turned cotton balls into cotton candy. I don't know if you know this, but I am an astrophysicist, and here are 3 chemistry-related things astronomers do differently than chemists:

1. The definition of metal
I have noticed in recent times there is a meme floating around in our astro community. It is something like:
"Astronomers after classifying every element other than hydrogen and helium as metal:
You know, I'm something of a chemist myself"
This is so true. This is because most of us usually focus on stars. And stars are mostly made of hydrogen. And stars make up most of galaxies. We sometimes measure the metallicity of stars, i.e, how much "metal" there is in a star. Everything other than hydrogen and helium falls in the category of "metal. Boron, carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, iron, etc are all metals. This is because we need to know how heavy the element is. Any other property of the element doesn't matter. The heavier elements are metals. People who do these are called astrochemists. And yes, it's true that planetary astronomers know more about chemistry.

2. Dust meaning
In optical astronomy, sometimes people complain about "dust" ruining their observations. Some of them may talk about the atmospheric dust (dust in our atmosphere). But in this case, some may talk about "dust" around the thing they are observing. Let's take a star for an example. When they see some light being blocked by something inconsistently, they assume it is dust. Usually they can be made from basically anything. Hydrogen and helium to acetic acid and benzene. They would all be considered dust. This is because none of the elements properties matter except for the fact that they block light from the star.

3. What is "H two"
I remember long ago when my professor asked me "what do stars need to survive?" I said "H two". She said "no it's not correct". I was like "no it's totally correct. If this is wrong then my whole life was a lie." After a short argument I said "no. Stars need molecular hydrogen to survive." She said "yes, that is correct. But why did you say H two at first? I thought you were talking about ionised hydrogen" This is when I learned in chemistry H2 is molecular hydrogen (that's why I said H two) and in astronomy H(II) is ionised hydrogen (that's what she thought I said).

Yes. We're pretty bad at chemistry. But this does not mean we hate chemistry. We love chemistry. Whenever we see a new phenomenon, and can't explain it with astrophysics, we want to explain it with chemistry before anything else.

Interesting concept! Food for thought - instead of starting with cellulose as your polysaccharide (which is tough to break down), why don't you consider starting with a starch? They're easy to make from potatoes or corn. I believe it's then possible to extract the amylose by treating them with an alcohol (methanol definitely works and can be boiled off after...ethanol might also work). You can then break the amylose down relatively quickly with amylase. Theoretically, that could eventually break everything down into almost pure maltose, which obviously has a higher melting point than glucose, and might suit your cotton candy making process better. Alternatively, you could use maltase to break the maltose down into glucose for use with other glucose-requiring projects.

Theoretically you could then use part of the glucose you made to regenerate alcohol by fermentation, which you could use in the amylose extraction above. Depending on the proportioning and yields, you could maybe get an almost self-sustaining process

Did you rinse the charcoal with distilled water before filtering your sugar mixture through it? If not, that's probably why it became so cloudy; in the fishtank hobby many newbies often forget to rinse their filtration first and the water becomes cloudy. Completely harmless to fish and to people, and charcoal is relatively safe to ingest so long as you aren't on any medication. I like all your videos success or failure. Always interesting and usually fun, too. Your problem here is a fundamental error in your use of language. Glucose isn’t sugar (sucrose, or table sugar). Sugar is a mixture of glucose and fructose (about 50/50). Glucose is a saccharide. (In its powdered form glucose is dextrose). Fructose is a saccharide. (Maltose, lactose, galactose, among others are all saccharides.) Glucose has a “sweetness” way, way less than fructose. Glucose is the saccharide that comes out of corn. 100% corn syrup is 100% glucose. (Pure corn syrup is very hard to find now. Karo syrup used to be pure glucose.) High fructose corn syrup (HFCS) is simply pure corn syrup (glucose) that has been chemically snd mechanically altered to have anywhere from 40% to 75% fructose. The relative percentages between glucose and fructose depends on the intended use of the HFCS.
What you needed to do to make the glucose (it’s not sugar, remember) you “distilled” from the cotton balls into cotton candy was add fructose sufficient to get table sugar (sucrose) or convert come of the glucose into fructose the way corn syrup producers convert glucose into sucrose. I believe sucrose as it it found in a bag of C&H sugar, for instance, is 45% glucose and 55% fructose, although those numbers may be backwards. It’s been a decade or so since I read this stuff.
Also, to make carnival quality cotton candy you need a little red food coloring. Cotton candy does have a slight caramelized taste from the heat used but it is very slight. I think that is what makes the taste of cotton candy distinctive from the taste of granulated sugar.

the reason why your yield in cotton candy is so little and why there was just mostly syrup at first is due to the fact that the sugar you used wasnt crushed into a finer dust. most cotton candy sugars is alot finer than the big chunks you put in because it heats up to make the cotton candy. you're cooking it twice over so putting a big piece of hardened candy ofcourse is just going to melt again, whereas if you put in a candy/sugar dust (like cotton candy sugar) you would've had cotton candy wisps immediately. (if you ever do this again, please, crush it into a Finer Dust.)

Just a PSA, this is high school chem level filtering. To properly wash what is left on a filter you REMOVE it and put it in a beaker and mix thoroughly with solvent and then filter it again. You do NOT just add more solvent to the clump of insolubles in the filter. That is noob level and this person never learns proper technique.

Also the "dirtiness" of the sugar is cause sulfuric acid and heat BURNS the sugar. So he lost lots of it. Much better to use phosphoric acid for virtually EVERYTHING you can use sulfuric for. Much gentler and better in every way. Since the burned sugar is not a salt or acid, you need to use activated charcoal to remove it not DI resin.

Any time you have something that's stubborn to break down, break it down yourself first. The smaller you make it, the more surface area you open up to be acted upon by whatever agent you are using. From using a grinder, mortar and pestle, or even a ball mill you can take it smaller and smaller until you have such a fine powder that it's like talc. At that point there's hundreds of times the surface area exposed to your reactant compared to leaving it whole. It'll make the process far easier as it doesn't have to break the bonds that make up the strands, it just has to act on the material itself.
Most people use activated carbon to clean aquarium water. Sugar needs nucleation sites to make crystals, often you use a seed crystal to start the process. Take a cup of sugar and add it to a half cup of water, heat it up and then let it cool off. It'll harden but there won't really be any crystals. Now do the same thing but drop in a single piece of table sugar and watch as crystals start forming off of it. It's an elementary school level science project.
The thing about cotton candy machines is they are made for fine crystal table sugar not huge chunks. If you would've ground your sugar first it would've worked far better.

Biologist here wanted to add some things: the cotton fibers are not just cellulose. They are super elongated cells (up to 6cm) from the outer membrane of the seeds. So there is a lot of cellulose (more than 90% cellulose) but there are lots of cell molecules too
So in the exterior of the cell wall there are waxes and oils (that may had stopped the cellulase from reacting), inside there is primary wall with cellulose and pectins, inside of wich there is the thick, almost pure cellulose secondary wall. And inside the lumen or cytoplasm wich is dehydrated but contains DNA, proteins (like lots of sucrose syntase ie.), fats and other sugars (although I guess most of the proteins would be degraded ln the acid)

Also not a cotton candy expert by any means, but in my experience of home cotton candy making for my niece & nephew, even when using table sugar it doesn't take very long for the candy to kind of "set", reducing in volume and getting harder and denser. From my experience running a cotton candy stall at a state fair, no such issues - there, I used something called "floss sugar", which a quick google search shows would contain granulated sugar, corn syrup, citric acid, and salt among various dyes and artificial flavorings. My guess would be these added ingredients provide more stability to the sugar threads, but I suppose a professional quality cotton candy machine might also somehow contribute. I'd suggest giving Ann Reardon a call and doing some further testing.

I don't know if the caramelization has much to do with the sugar working with the machine. I think it's the moisture content. Pure sucrose doesn't work in the machine either, but most candy, like Jolly Ranchers will. In cooking terms, the candy should be between the Soft-Crack and Hard-Crack stages. In candy making these are determined by the temperature of the candy as it cooks, which will relate to the water content. As the water content drops, the temperature of the candy goes up. Straight table sugar is too dry to work, and I think your first attempt was too wet.

I wonder if the caramelized glucose was more hygroscopic than normal sucrose. When I was in pastry school, one of the labs I did was to assemble a croquembouche (cream puffs stacked in the shape of a tree with caramelized sugar holding it together, garnished with a spun cage of caramelized sugar). The class was in the middle of the summer and I had assembled part of it one day, and put it away to finish the next day. When I got there the next day, the caramel had soaked up a ton of moisture from the air, liquifying my caramel ruining the whole thing, forcing me to start again. Since the cotton candy strands increase its surface area, giving more of it access to humid air, I'd venture a guess that that's what happened here.

Also 200C is crazy hot for sugar. I'm surprised it didn't come out black. I think the hottest I'd go is 160C otherwise it starts tasting like charcoal, but beggars can't be choosers. Well done.

I think that the goopieness of the sugar you got is due to the temperatures that they ended up as. I've made different kinds of candy with sugar and the temperature (i.e. the food dehydrator which still cooks the food you put in it) changes the consistency drastically depending on the temperature it's at when it's boiled down or reduced in water. Higher temperatures result in more crystallized structures while lower temperatures end up more gummy or stringy.

I'd call the end result a success. If you want to try a followup video, I suggest looking up The King Of Random's cotton candy videos. They toyed around seeing how different sugars and candies behave in a cotton candy maker. In the end, you might have actually gotten the best results you could get with pure(-ish) glucose. It might only be possible to get fluffier candy by blending with another sugar or by reducing the cotton candy maker's heat output. This is going to be one of my favorite videos on the channel. People will not realize how complicated you were trying to do, since it is the same process that is used in bioreactors to make bioethanol, which involves many processes with microorganisms.

At first I thought which route you were going to choose, chemical or biological. When I saw that you tried the biological route first, I was happy and worried, because although you are a fantastic chemist, biochemistry differs a lot from traditional chemistry. Cellulases are a group of proteins that break one of the most complicated bonds, β (1 → 4) of cellulose, whose function is in fact to chemical and mechanical resistance, and that very few organisms generate, most bacteria. To completely break down cellulose into glucose, several types of cellulases would be required. Also, you have to remember that enzymatic catalysts differ from inorganic ones in that they act at a certain temperature and pH, that is why the first test did not work. In addition, cotton is not only composed of cellulose, it also has proteins and other compounds that make it resistant to the action of enzymes. In biochemistry we usually take previous steps to separate cellulose from the rest of the compounds.
Then I saw that you finally opted for acid hydrolysis. It is a way that generates more by-products and requires more steps to purify, but without a doubt simpler and that as a chemist you master much better.It is very likely that the efficiency was low for two reasons: first because cotton is not cellulose. As I said it also has proteins and other compounds, and you may have calculated that there was more cellulose in total. Second, because, as I have said before, by acid hydrolysis, various by-products are obtained, such as small chains of sugars, or acid sugars that have a charge and that possibly the ionic exchange resin has trapped. Anyway it went well. As a tip, if you want to try next time you can use lugol to see if there are many traces of polysaccharides left. The lugol changes color with complex sugars but not with simple ones, so if it changes color you could check if there are still branched sugars from the cellulose without hydrolyzing.
The result has been good and this together with the video of the transparent wood are one of my favorite videos. Every time I see one of your videos it fascinates me because as a biologist I have basic knowledge of chemistry but it seems super complex as well as beautiful all the processes you do. And with these that involve biochemistry that I do understand is like seeing things from a totally new point of view. I will be looking forward to your next video!

Cooks would tell you glucose sugars are typically added specifically to keep the food from having a pronounced crystalline structure (really texture). It is so hygroscopic it absorbs moisture from the environment and softens and moistens the final product.

It's added to (some) fudge to fight the "grainy" texture, but if you add too much it'll never set.

Any recipe with corn syrup that's essentially why it's there.

The concentrated acid would consume the sugar generated simply by burning it. You can achieve a higher yield by using dilute sulphuric acid 2% combined with a higher temperature say around 160 degrees centigrade. Or with 4% acid and a 121 degrees centigrade. Neutralisation could be with caustic with will result in soluble sodium sulphate and water. Freezing/cooling the solution would then cause the sodium sulphate to precipitate out up to 90%. One word of caution is that the usage of acid for hydrolysis also results in HMF formation and some furfural formation. I’m a bit divided on the use of a mixed bed for removal as it probably would not be able to eliminate conductivity that easily. Instead I would recommend a macroporous iER anion with a high exchange capacity. This combined with Activated carbon should decolourise your solution.

You should make some biodiesel. It's quite simple. Buy monosaturated  canola cooking oil and react it with the right amount of an oxo acid preferably methoxide. Caustic lye chrystals dissolved in methanol. Wear eye protection. Add the proper ( stoichometry) amount of methoxide to the bottle of monosaturated canola oil and quickly shake vigorously ( make sure there is no water present for it could react explosively. There can be no moisture while doing this reaction). Let it sit for 24 hours. The byproduct glycerine will sit at the bottom. Carefully pour the top level of the biodiesel ( esterified oil) off the glycerine byproduct without getting the glycerine with the oil into another bottle. Next step is to add a little distilled water in the separated biodiesel and cap it. Rotate the bottle a few times ( don't shake) to separate the residual soap it produced during the reaction. Allow it to sit for another 24hrs and decant the oil off the soap contaminated water. Now you have pure biodiesel.

Forgive me if this is a really basic or obvious question, but how do you have the acid consume the cellulose without then further going on to dehydrate the sugar and turn it all to carbon? I mean it's clear from the color and flecks of black that you're making some carbon, but how do you run the reaction for two hours without consuming most if not all of your sugar? Is the acid just too dilute compared to the amount of water already there to prefer creating more water molecules? does the sulfuric acid prefer the cellulose to glucose? Coincidentally I think that might be the source of your low yield because I definitely saw flecks of carbon being made when you added your initial cotton ball.

Also I think the fact it shrank and got harder so fast could have been the result of how hygroscopic it was, that's a lot of surface area to grab water out of the air.

Okay, I'm not a chemist myself but I looked it up, and your cotton balls may have had dioxins in them resulting from treatments to clean and bleach the cotton when they were made. However, dioxins are pretty much insoluble in water, and may be vulnerable to acids, so your process should have gotten rid of most or all that were in there. Rum tends to be brownish, so it's possible some of the glucose was caramelized before you finished cleaning up the sugar water. It's also possible there were other materials in there.

One thing I'd have done, if the equipment was available, would be to use a mass spectrometer. Of course, those are expensive pieces of equipment, so you might not have one yourself yet. Plus your audience mostly wouldn't have one either, but I wouldn't let that stop you.

Also, letting the machine heat up more than 5 minutes also will make a difference.

Hard crack (cotton candy sugar) is 150-155c. The last step of heating the sugar on the hot plate, use a laser thermo to temp the sugar to 146c (the top is cooler than the actual sugar). Remove from the plate and let it cool. Then break it up into powder. It can b run through the cotton candy machine, and there would b little to no caramelization in the sugar. Heating the sugar to 185c is essentially caramelizing the sugar turning it into a hard caramel. I know this is after the fact, but at the freezer step was when you should consult hard candy makers, especially those in humid climates.

I know you will ABSOLUTELY never make this again, but if there's any other scientist here in the Comments willing to try this, caramel is at least 4 cups of sugar to 1 spoon of water, so imagine the amount of liquid you would actually need to extract for it to be solid. Also caramel has diferent setting temperatures, so if you want taffy you'll heat if up to a certain point, if you want molasses its a diferent temperature, if you want hard candy, etc.
The higher you cook the sugar, the harder it will be at room temperature. The more water you add, the more of a sauce it will be.
Also, cotton candy machines are designed to work with granulated sugar so maybe smash the sugar into smaller pieces first for it to thread better

I can give you a hint on where did the glucose go... I made similar experiments to convert biomasses to sugar and than selectively catalyze the formation of furans, I could analyze the batches with an HPLC.
When you sticked the cotton in the acid, it is true that it dissolved the cellulose bond more and more, but you didn't consider that in the meantime the acid on the single molecule procede on dehydrate it (forming other species like furans, that gave the brown/yellowish colour and are slightly apolar so you couldn't get rid of it completely with the resins but more with the active carbon) and than braking those even more with acid catalyzed rehydration that gives formic and levoulinic acid (this is the side reaction that lowered the most the yield) that where blocked in the resins.
I hope I was useful, anyway thank you so much, I follow you since a long time and you're great!
PS: I wondered but never tried, is thete a way to complex the cellulose with the Switzer reagent (sorry if I wrote it wrong maybe) and than keep it definitely separated, did you ever think to this reaction route?

Dude, you did it wrong. I feel like your videos get 90% of the way there but fail in the last 10%. In order to be truly convincing you needed to end up with a white powdery substance that we all know and love as sugar then put that in the machine with pink/red food coloring and have real cotton candy.
Where did you go wrong?? Well I'm no smart butt chemistry major, but my search engine bing took me to website that told me how they get to white sugar powder.
Where you went wrong is before you dried your product *you need to separate the sugar from the brown stuff called mollasses*. You simply failed to do that and hence you ended up with a product more akin to brown sugar. Not the white powder stuff.
Cotton ball mollasses would be another story in itself. But I digress. You needed to spin your original product in a centrifuge to separate out the heavier mollasses (which you did not do - your filtering isn't going to catch all the minerals in mollasses) THEN use the food dryer and produce a product akin to window glass that is sugar.
Also, start with more cotton balls. You had too little product at the end and they're cheap.

This video was really fun to watch, and regarding the cotton candy machine, I wanted to mention a few things!

I personally own a smaller model gotten from Vat19, advertised as the hard candy cotton candy machine. This was before I learned that ANY cotton candy machine can be a hard candy one. I assume the difference is that the sugar cup on mine might be a little bit taller and might not require you to break up the hard candy, such as Jolly Ranchers or Butterscotch.

The sounds you heard while your machine spun around were likely due to an imbalance of weight. I've noticed that placing two jolly ranchers in my machine (what the directions suggest), if they aren't almost exactly across from one another, the machine makes a loud noise as it spins, the weight imbalance causing the shaking. However, if I manage to get the candy to be even, it runs smoothly!

In addition, what you made was akin to Easter Grass or Fiberglass candy, and that happens when the machine isn't hot enough! When you put the crushed pieces in, I noticed that they didn't melt or fizzle, and when that happened to me, it was because I tried to make the candy before letting the machine heat fully!

Btw my guy, next time you use Alibaba, and talk to sellers, here are some tips...those guys barely know english, or they use a translator to help them communicate;
1.) Do not use compound words (like "don't")
2.) Keep is very short, and very simple. "PURE cellulase?"
3.) If you didn't get a decent response, ask again with different wording. You can also ask to speak to someone that knows english. The last thing they want to do is take a return.
4.) Manufacturing specifications are never wrong on there from my experience, but they do lack a bit from manufacturer to manufacturer. If the ingredients list only cellulase it will be only cellulase.

I would say, you got an ok yield but lost quite a bit of sugar to the exchange resin.
While glucose can take a nuetral charge in water, it can form both anionic and cationic complexes in water, and catalytic amounts of sulfuric acid helps form both.

That said, there was a way to get a better yield.
Instead of using concentrated reactants, you need to use more dilute solutions of calcium carbonate and sulfuric acid/glucose. More dilute solutions will allow the calcium sulfate to be a finer precipitate, trapping less sugar, and removes the need to use the exchange resin.
Further, boiling down the diluted glucose solution would allow it more opportunities to re-polymerize.

Finally, the irony here is that you just needed to crystallize out the glucose/sucrose from the solution, rather than passing it through an exchange resin. Especially if the pH was nuetral.

It needs to get to 171c for spun sugar, which isn't quite the same as cotton candy. If it tastes burnt, you likely burned the sugar past caramelization.

as someone who knows almost nothing about actual science/chemistry and A Lot about candy making, i have some thoughts about about why the candy didn't fluff up properly+hardened so fast and possible ways to combat that if you'd ever like to try again:
1- the sugar crystals were too big to be properly spun, meaning you made something closer to a taffy base than the hard candy base necessary. This is actually the easiest to fix! the chunks of glucose just n33d to be broken into finer crystals: it doesn't completely fix the issue but allows those individual crystals to be more evenly exposed to the heat and melt much easier and more consistently, so more air can be worked into the base and it will stay soft.
2- it looked like your sugar was cooked a bit too long here, which is fine for chewy candies like a taffy or soft caramel but can completely ruin a cotten candy base. It takes a lot of practice to learn what exact color your cooked sugar should be, and that method may not even work here because the sugar is already an off-brown, so drop testing would probably work best. (For those that don't know, drop testing candy basically means dropping a small amount of the still hot candy into ice water to s33 what texture the candy will be when cooled. I'm guessing Mr. Nilered's candy was at the "drop tail" stage, when he n33ded it to be at the "hard ball" stage.)
3- there may have b33n too much moisture in your lab for the candy to aerate properly. It's the hardest thing to control, and the most likely to ruin a batch of spun candy. the only real thing you can do to manage this is wait for a low humidity, mid temperature day and try again.

- You need the air between the sugar grains to allow for better aeration, which the machine can strip the grains into crystals more quickly. Cotton candy works because of the speed it goes from a grain to a liquid then to a crystal. The result might not be so 'burnt'. The way it is, the sugar temp, as a blob in the machine, has to get so high, and heat the sugar to the point where it liquefies and eventually the machine can strip the sugar into crystallised webs. During this long period of time, it will burn.

Before checking the video I immediately thought "Nile's going to cook the cotton with HCl, then neutralise it". Kinda surprised you tried an enzymatic route at first, and then H₂SO₄.

HCl would be cleaner overall. If you add it in controlled amounts, you can simply neutralise it and leave the resulting salt in solution (salty sweets are a thing); it isn't so eager to oxidise everything in the path (that brown stuff was likely charcoal, from the concentrated H₂SO₄); and sulphates are yucky, they always have that off-putting taste. Yield would've been better, too, as you aren't literally chemically burning the sugar.

Also: if using calcium as a neutraliser, calcium oxide→hydroxide would be a better deal than carbonate. It wouldn't foam, and I bet you could find food grade CaO in any shop that sells Mexican products (it's required for corn nixtamalisation).

When cooking, glucose is actually what you add when you want to stop sugar from crystallising.

I am a biochemistry student. I have finished working on a project freeze drying biological material. The reason why dry enzyme powder will have sugar added to it is that during the freeze drying process the enzyme can be damaged. To prevent this damage, chemicals known as lyoprotectants can be added to the formulation (e.g. the enzyme). The most common lyoprotectants are sugars, typically, sucrose or trehalose. Maltodextrin is often used since it has a lyoprotectant property and good thermal qualities too.
What you produced with the dehydrator and the freezer looks a lot like caramelized sugar, which you normally make with sugar, water, and heat.

You're making a food item Nile, you should do food chemistry.
As in, the way we would've cleaned up sugar in the past was likely using egg, which could be filtered out after the sugar water was heated.
The protein in the eggs grabs onto many impurities, similarly eggs were used to clarify salt in ancient times too.
Simply add raw egg white to a near boiling mixture, and the egg will cook and grab the impurities at the same time, filter and discard the egg and continue your processing.
Milk was also used to clarify color and make alcoholic beverages less cloudy, but in alcohol the reason it works is simply that the milk fully disperses, before denaturing and curdling in the alcohol, when filtered the curds hold onto the off bitter tastes, and colors.
Milk worked for salt purification too, but egg whites were preferred since they could be filtered a little easier than milk curds

TlDr egg whites and milk can clarify salt, alcohol, and most off-colored and acidic liquids.
When your sugar was in a highly acidic state, it may have been dangerous to attempt to use milk, however eggs would simply denature quicker in those conditions and consequently would still work as a clarifying agent.
It is unknown to me if this process also steals sugar from the mix.

And secondly, you really should take the sugar to the "Hard Crack" stage, at about 148° C (180° C is well past "Burnt Sugar") which should bring it to about 1% water content, then let it cool to room temp (or freeze) then grind into granules with a coffee grinder.
Cotton Candy machines don't do well with larger granules or chunks, and the machine should be preheated before pouring about a TBSP into the opening.

Wow something I know really well and can comment on. First, extracting sugar is a compete pain in the ass to do.... Anything... With it. Sugar science is basically all yellow science, it's crap.

But let's talk about getting that sugar out. I have going the long road and ion exchange resins. They don't work. Sure there is a bunch of literature talking about using, but it isn't really good, and I have a suspicion most of us bad.

The real answer, tangential flow membrane filtration. That's basically the only way to reasonably filter out the salts and concentrate the sugars. This is what is used in the dairy industry to demineralized milk before it's concentrated.

Anyway, fun to watch stuff I know what too much about.
